Last night in class, we were discussing that week's assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter deals with "implacement" and the second, "displacement." In the first chapter, Casey makes the distinction that our contemporary world and culture revolves around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He argues that using place as the center of culture fosters a more grounded community. (This is a very rough summation, a disclaimer in case my professor or any classmate happens to read this post.) So far, this book is the first reading that has truly resonated with me.

It puts the ball in the net or it gets the hose again. Absolutely amazing, I have nothing negative to say about this game as it's exceeded my expectations and will probably exceed yours too. Fluid movement, bug- and crash-free, lots of story and content to keep you engaged, with options for each day, including multiple practices, events (sponsorships), and even games. This review is purely based on playing MyCareer, and so far it's 10/10. Facescan worked really well for me (used it twice, the first attempt resulted in a misshapen forehead though..). Keep in mind, using the MyNBA2K17 app allows for free facescanning and daily VC earnings. #sellout

Magic fans beware... Wizards is hesitant to create a decent digital game. At its core, Magic: The Gathering is a social game meant to be enjoyed with friends (or frenemies), sharing laughter, trash talk, and game-winning moments. Wizards of the Coast seems to have forgotten this. If you choose to play with friends, you can't earn gold, which is crucial. Gold is so crucial that they've implemented a daily cap, understandable given that it unlocks everything in-game. However, be prepared for a long and monotonous 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, with whom you can't even communicate. If you choose to play for free, it will take you roughly 4 hours a day for upwards of a month, solo, to unlock the cards.

Being the 3rd installment in the trilogy, I'll address the drawbacks first. I generally dislike prequels as they technically move the story backward rather than forward (a common issue with prequels). However, they often provide more narrative depth. The combat feels sloppy and lacks the sharpness that Arkham City achieved. As of writing this recommendation (26/10/2013), a game-breaking bug prevents a side mission from being completed (the main story remains unaffected). Some gadgets are assigned to inconvenient hotkeys, requiring your hand to travel across the keyboard to access them. Although it may seem minor, this can disrupt your combo during combat.

They basically fixed Shadow Warrior (2013), i.e. The boss fights are awesome, weapons feel very nice (maybe not as good as D44M's ones, but still solid), enemies aren't too resilient (if you're not too inexperienced with handling elemental and upgrade aspects). The upgrade system is really balanced and once you get the hang of it, it's not too tedious. The elemental aspects and limited ammo softly encourage you to use different weapons. Lots of cool unique (being the key word here while comparing SW2 to Borderlands' formula of 'rng' weapons) weapons that stay viable throughout most of the game. The music is great, especially the main theme and of course Stan Bush's contributions.

So many things were made wrong. I don't even know how to start this review. This all refers to my career. My player is an outside scorer, point guard, 1.71m, with maxed stats and all necessary perks. Now, tell me, why does the shooting skill depend on a person's height? Why can a person who is 1.74m not become as good a shooter as a person with 1.71m? I'm 1.87m in real life, made my first player with this height and noticed then that I couldn't reach a higher skill than 89. Why? That's pure discrimination! And why doesn't the game inform me of this before I create a character, or even when I reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?

I think this Assassin's Creed nailed the mechanics down on all fronts (ship battles, sailing, hunting, parkour, etc). I felt much more attached to this character as well. The story starts out extremely rough but does get significantly better as you play (I think this is the case with every AC game personally). Edward was quite an interesting character, and so were all the side characters. I felt like all the collectibles actually served a purpose in this AC game, which I never experienced in the previous ones, and maybe it's because they had a bigger impact on the game. They definitely weren't required, but they were fun to obtain and you got rewarded in a very balanced way.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is alright, as long as you have the money to purchase gun parts, which would be my main complaint with this game: it's pay-to-win. If I could get past that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and HRV is an excellent concept. I'd take this game over any Call of Duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransaction format is off-putting for me. If you are alright with this model, then by all means, have fun. But if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, just let this one slide; it's not our cup of tea.

While not perfect, this game has been greatly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death lead to some frustration. I'm on my first playthrough and I lost my main character around hour 10 of 20ish. I would have really liked a save to reload at that point. I've since picked up a 3rd-party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. Plus, the aiming reticule is on the small side, and the zoom is underpowered. With all that said, it's been a blast. I'm not normally a zombie fan, but the combination of strategy, missions, first-person shooter/beat 'em up is great. I've been playing it as often as I can get away... Just one more mission, just one more supply run – or I'm running away and want to get safe before shutting the game down.

An absolutely great strategy game. Having played every single other wargame (European Escalation, and ALB), I have to say this one fits well. The number of units is impressive. Not sure exactly how many units there are, but there's a vast array. Graphics are just beautiful, sounds are great, and the gameplay overall is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is very entertaining as well, no I am not kidding. However, if anyone thinks this game is 'easy', or if you are new to the strategy genre, it could take you quite some time to master. Do not get upset, you will lose a lot of units. Just make sure you plan ahead, always have anti-air, and anti-tank.

I was initially biased against this game before playing it. I wasn't even sure about purchasing it. I don't know, the portal gun and portal concept seemed unusual to me, despite my fondness for science fiction. Boy, was I wrong. The jokes and voice acting in this game are phenomenal - just amazing. It's not overly cheesy (okay, it's sometimes cheesy). Different story characters have their own sense of humor. Those characters genuinely have distinct personalities. And the level design is impressive. By the way, I never played the first Portal game. One of these days, I plan to if I can spare the time. I wouldn't have played it if I hadn't played the sequel.

Let's start with the pros and cons, followed by my thoughts on this game. +Some of the best characters +Good story +Loads of content +Customizable character (you can be male or female, whatever you like) +You can have a relationship with most of your companions (yes, fangirls, you can have a love interest) -Poor graphics (I don't think graphics really matter anyway) -Weird and awkward love scenes -Invisible walls -There's one mission that, in my opinion, was boring, but everyone has different tastes -+ Um, this isn't really bad or good, but for those who care, your protagonist can't talk. Okay, now for my thoughts. I love this game. This game is probably one of the best RPGs or games in general I have ever played. So, if you're an RPG fan, you probably already have this game.

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember (at least in the UK) watching the ever-irritating Timmy Mallet just for the five-minute Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others are back, and instantly recognisable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is there. Graphically, the cell-shaded presentation is perfect, and very, very Generation One. But aside from that, it's actually a very enjoyable game. The combat mechanics are extremely well done. Transforming mid-fight is often a necessity, and woven seamlessly into combos, making it quite unlike High Moon's excellent War for/Fall of Cybertron games. Another distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, but some enemies (e.g. Seekers) require a switch to a ranged blaster for optimal results.

I downloaded the game and played it briefly, but it was unimpressive. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing. There's a bug where it claims there's an update to the terms of service, and clicking 'accept' only makes it pop up again. You have to restart the client for it to work. Although that's not terrible, I question why linking my Steam and Gface accounts is necessary. They claim it's for DLC, but why is that required? It's also irreversible, so now a company I'm not invested in has access to my Steam information. The game itself is mediocre. It's easily recognizable as a COD clone, except somehow they managed to make the gunplay worse... How is that even possible?

4k+ at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and includes Neptune gear. What's not to love? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo Excellent port and a great entry point if new to the series. Just keep in mind there's lots of (skippable) talking. As usual, I'd suggest using a gamepad, but personally, I had no problems with a keymouse/mouse setup, both completely rebindable. The price is about right, and I wouldn't have been unhappy about a purchase. More than half the DLC is included free, which is still plenty to play with. Recommended game to all JRPG/anime/visual novel fans, provided you don't mind long breaks between the action. Cheers. No commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

I experienced no performance issues even at release, and after all these patches it runs smoothly. In my opinion, this is a really great and fun game, although the format may be somewhat annoying (where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies every time you progress the story). I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments (where you can play as Batman and one more character), and the ability to use the controller for most segments of the game but the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments was greatly appreciated. Driving your batmobile around the free-roam city, including when chasing the APC commanders, is actually quite enjoyable once you figure out how to use the brakes to skid around corners (and when you master that, driving around the city is really quite enjoyable!)

Damn fine aaa fps shooter - that's the bottom line. It's visually stunning, sounds great and plays exceptionally well - great fps mechanics, engaging story, cool characters, flawless voice acting, and an awesome soundtrack. Not for the faint hearted though - some of those cutscenes were pretty darn cruel and vivid. But when a game overall is so great, it's easier to spot the flaws, and here they are as I saw 'em: - no sli support - what a disappointment? I had to put the game away until I upgraded my card, as it ran poorly on my old dual gpu gtx 590. Ensure you have a fairly decent single gpu card. - ridiculously small obstacles are often unclimbable.

English is not my native language, I am Dutch. Please disregard any typing or grammatical mistakes in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into a few categories: - graphics - controls - sound - gameplay - replayability. Graphics: the game has a comic-like style. The graphics are very slick, with no unnecessary details and nice color schemes. It totally works for this game. The graphics can be set to 'high' without stressing your system. I run this game on an i5 Pentium processor, with an Nvidia GeForce 710m card, 8GB memory, and it runs smoothly (Windows 8.1). Controls: the game can be played with a keyboard and mouse, but also with an Xbox controller.

You can see by the hours I put into this game that I thoroughly enjoy it. This is everything I wished a search game from COD would be. However, don't buy this game thinking it's like COD, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It's a game in its own class and should be treated as such. I've lost count of how many times I hear new players rant and complain about getting killed quickly. Oh, the shock of getting shot in the face and dying. It's not like that doesn't happen in real life or anything. Edit: Having played this game for a while now, I've invested a significant amount of money into it. One of the best multiplayer games around. A great alternative to play when you're not in the mood for CS:GO.

I'm 2 hours in and am thoroughly enjoying this game. So hilarious. Gameplay is solid, art design is stunning, music is surprisingly high quality and fitting, the story/world has me intrigued, and the puzzles are entertaining. But the standout aspect of this game is its comedy. If you've played any RPG since the dawn of video game RPGs, you'll laugh at the various jokes, parodies, and references; if you're new to RPGs, you'll still appreciate the game's humor. If you played Final Fantasy 7 or X, you absolutely need to play this game - without giving too much away... I had to pause after 2 hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far.

I'm really sorry, I try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I really didn't enjoy this game. The description sounded right up my alley, but the execution fell short. I love puzzle and exploration games, but I found this game to be completely unintuitive, and even after looking up how to progress, I still simply didn't find the gameplay itself enjoyable. It also lacks a pause button, or if it does have one, I never found it. Considering that many sequences in the game are timed, this seems like a critical oversight. I also feel like this game is more cut scene than gameplay, and I end up just sitting around, waiting impatiently.

This game... Phew, where to even start. It was absolutely breathtaking, from story to graphics, I was hooked. The story wasn't just any story, but actually felt like I was that person, trying to figure out what came next in the story my character was telling. Gameplay was great, and I learned a lot about myself through this game, mainly my fear of heights, which I never had a problem with until the ice caverns. My gut churned the whole time, but I kept going for Uncle Fred. If you guys made a DLC or second game, I would be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thanks to everyone involved in making this; you created an absolutely beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build your civilization to achieve a specific goal or 'victory'. In previous games, you progressed through the earth's timeline, experiencing periods like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age; however, in this game, you're set in the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I enjoy about this game is that 2K took a new approach and added mechanics such as the affinity system and orbital layer. What I didn't enjoy was that these new mechanics could be overwhelming at times. What I think could be improved in this game is that they could incorporate some new artwork, such as the environment you experience when communicating with another leader, to enhance the overall experience.

Great game! Tons of replayability and a very fun zombie survival experience. Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever played. Edit: after playing 60+ hours, I can honestly say this is one of the better, more 'realistic' zombie games. It's very much designed like a survival horror, where you must conserve ammo, heal your own wounds when you bleed out, take pills when you're infected, etc. Also, I find the zombies to feel very natural and well-animated for a free-to-play game. P.S.: I would recommend getting 1 or 2 friends to play with, but the community is super friendly, and you can usually make friends or chat with people in the chat or over voice comms.

02/07/2014 - it's a shame I can't thoroughly recommend or enjoy this game, as from the short time I've played it, I know I'd be addicted if it didn't have the following two game breakers. No Aussie servers - one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage and creates unbearable lag. Mind you, I played through the offline training mode and it was stuttering and lagging as well (how does that even happen?). Couple that with the poor ping, and it just ruins the experience. Everything is plagued by artifacts - the menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game. I've never had this happen before with this card and thought it might not like my overclock. I set my GPU back to stock and, sure enough, it didn't make a difference.

Very late last night, I finished this. Although the story isn't particularly deep or interesting, the storytelling is what makes it stand out. The atmosphere is rich and immersive, and the numerous collectibles do a great job of fleshing it out. I gained a lot of insight into the world of Batman, so it was somewhat disappointing that there were so few bosses in the game. However, there are plenty of future games to rectify that. The combat offers the right amount of challenge, but it's slightly on the easy side. Leveling up Batman wasn't very satisfying. It's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign that add nice new gameplay mechanics. Gaining access to previously unreachable places creates a nice sense of progression.

'To the Moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the most memorable of my life at that. Think Telltale's The Walking Dead is sad? Hohoho! Well, it's no match for 'To the Moon'! Never before have I felt so emotionally drained yet fulfilled over something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls can be a bit finicky and the gameplay isn't the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I didn't care one bit. Plus, the humor in the game is great as well and it doesn't intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story... And the Doctor Who references are endless and delightful.

Bastion is a bloody brilliant game, with a really great storyline. Set after a calamity has occurred, you start to rebuild on the bastion. There's quite a lot of choice in the game, with the choice of what to build to gain an advantage, what weapons to use and what power-ups to equip them with, as well as what drinks to use to give you a bonus effect. The art style and music in the game are fantastic, everything looks so vibrant at times, who says the apocalypse has to be dull. Best of all, the game features narration based on what you, the player, do. So if you end up picking up a weapon then switch it for another in the armoury, the narration would say something about you taking along the new weapon.

I had originally purchased this game in early development, when the only currency was spacebux, and there was no 'tech tree'. This was when the game was enjoyable. All of the guns at this point were equally overpowered, so there were no issues with imbalance; everyone could kill anyone at any time. Also, the game used to provide unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You would think that for a game with 'bajillions of guns', they would at least offer more than 6 weapon slots and 3 loadouts before requiring payment for additional slots. At one point, I had about 3 pages worth of guns, and was planning new ideas for more, because personally, that's where I found it fun.

This game was a surprising gem. One often sees rave reviews of certain products that are often misleading. In this case, the reviews accurately reflect the fun of this neat little game. It is an odd yet intriguing mix between a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, and it pulls it off with style. I found myself enjoying characters that I wouldn't typically enjoy in other MOBA games. I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a try anyway. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and ended up trying out more as they were unlocked through gameplay. The art style and interface are oddly charming. As such, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper created from a card set for the game.

I just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game has had that effect on me. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are perfect. I look forward to every combat, and they've optimized combat extremely well. I had my doubts about the naval combat system, but it is so much fun to lay waste to multiple fleets at a time! The only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat looks overwhelming, just get out of there, regroup, and counter-attack. Thanks, devs, for an awesome experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought about many changes for the series, particularly for the series' protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series may be upset at the change to their beloved character, it's certainly for the better; and this new game by Ninja Theory proves it. DmC serves as the perfect point for newcomers to jump into the series. It shows the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante, and it chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to watch. Imagine the story follows Dante as he's introduced into the corrupt world he willfully chose to ignore.

Where do I start with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is absolutely charming, with so much detail put into it, and it's a bundle of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, and secrets. It's serious when it needs to be, but isn't a stranger to humorous moments. The character design is on point, with various characters having unique personalities and secrets. It stands out from other RPGs because you don't have to kill anyone, an underutilized concept in RPGs. With lots of inspiration from Earthbound, one of the best RPGs I've seen, you can tell it's going to be good. It easily has the best soundtrack I've heard in a long time.

I am recommending this solely because it's free, and might be a more 'enjoyable' experience for others. As for my experience, the 'game' had no impact on me. Half the story relies on shock value. I was neither shocked nor emotionally moved in any way by this. Maybe I'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simplistic to warrant a reaction from me. As for the other half of the game, it attempts to paint a picture (literally) of a person in mental decline. It explores obsession, hallucination, depression, and a few other themes. In theory, it's a cool idea. But the 'game' took me 10 minutes to complete, and that's with reading and taking in every bit of information I could.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then steps aside. It's an amazing way to test your mind while still being enjoyable. Although this game isn't as story-driven, it did give birth to one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play this game and beat it when I'm feeling bored, and I love to come back and see what gave birth to a legend and what is a legend. Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is quite simple to explain, at least. You use portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate a part of the puzzle. Two types of buttons are in the game: one that you press and one that requires a cube to be placed on it.

If you can overlook the bugs (which I personally only encountered two: one minor and the other quite annoying) edit: both bugs are resolved - one fix increased my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120 - and are looking for a space exploration game, I can definitely recommend this. Since most of these reviews focus on specs, I'll include mine: i5 6600k (~200€) Radeon RX480 (~200€) Z170 Pro Gaming (~150€) 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70€) ~650€ is definitely within the medium price range, though granted, this rig is quite new. Almost constant 60+ FPS on high settings with VSync enabled - I genuinely can't believe 90% of the comments saying they're rocking an overkill setup and getting 20FPS.

Remember Age of Mythology? Yeah, it's been that long since there's been an RTS game of such quality. Divinity: Dragon Commander reaches awfully close to the borders of my personal most favourite RTS game. Combine this with a huge Risk-like grand strategy mode and it hits the spot. I try not to be overly biased due to the fact that this game allows you to turn into a dragon, aiding your troops by supporting, attacking, and even commanding unit production, direction, and spawning at the same time. Honestly, I do like the complicated RTS games nowadays, such as Civ V. However, such games attempt to cram complex mechanics, charts, and resources into one complicated game mode, often to their detriment.

Undertale comes together to make something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title and the music is pleasant, but paired together they create some truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script runs the gamut from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all at once, and does this while turning RPG tropes on their head. And all of this without touching on the world, characters, story, gameplay... I could write whole pages about it. But instead, I'll just say this: if you like RPGs, play this game. If you like video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your passing, play this game.

I have only had this game for a few months, but in just that short amount of time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have transformed an already great game into an excellent one. The devs are very active in the community, and it really shows in the various discussion forums and developer diaries. There is a fairly steep learning curve to the game's mechanics, which I am still trying to master; however, this breadth of strategy allows you a myriad of ways to reach goals and capitalize on certain situations. The game, in my mind, is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself fully immersed in every session I play, regardless of how the play-through is going.

Warframe is an enjoyable game for the initial few hours of play. After those few enjoyable hours, you'll begin to notice that the only thing left for the game to offer is repetition in its combat, enemies, and gameplay. The one major high point for the game is that the developers are working diligently and release semi-frequent updates that generally include a substantial amount of content, from sweeping changes to some of the game's systems, new warframes, and other tweaks and features. It's a good game to play casually. Though I doubt it will hold your attention beyond a few months unless you genuinely enjoy grinding. The upside to all of this is that the game is free, so I'd recommend giving it a try. If you're looking for a quick fix, try it out.

This game is extremely dull. I bought it believing it was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy', a popular and enjoyable PS2 game. Sadly, it falls short. In this game, you absorb increasingly larger objects to grow bigger and absorb more. However, the gameplay isn't as smooth as it could be, the levels lack inventiveness, and the overall experience is a surreal, unsettling horror show. I don't mean an entertaining horror show, but one that leaves you feeling rather depressed and questioning the value of life. Every 'living' creature in this game, from small pets to human beings, makes me wonder if the creators had a fascination with taxidermy.

Alright. Let me explain a few things, as a person very interested in politics, I was intrigued when I first heard about this game. I thought, 'oh wow! a simulator of the road to becoming president! that sounds fun!' well, it really wasn't. The game starts you off and says you need to pick a side: Republican or Democrat, there is no Independent, or third party. A little disappointed, but still optimistic, I carried on to see what I could do. I will give the game credit, the character customization, although limited, is pretty fun to mess around with. It's the only time it's an option to wear your head or not in a campaign, literally.

My stats (at the time of writing this review): 
- 8.6 hours to reach the end 
- 10 collectibles found out of 25 
- zero achievements out of 15 

What I liked: 
- Visuals up until the last level (ice caves) 
- Although the story isn't great, the ending (after the closing credits) somewhat redeemed my time spent playing this game 

What I disliked: 
- The last level's visuals are unimpressive 
- The gameplay in the last level becomes significantly harder, making it a frustrating experience of repetition until you succeed 
- Achievements are overly challenging. There are 13 (out of 15) that less than 2.1% of players have achieved.

Pros: +graphics. Cons: -bugs (especially environmental issues, where you may get stuck or your shots may hit an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight of the enemy) -the game is overly hand-holding and babysitting -dumb AI -enemies always seem to know your location when spotted -enemies have godlike accuracy, which is frustrating, similar to the first Ghost Warrior. -poorly designed checkpoints and saves. -a dull story that I couldn't care less about. I won't recommend it unless it's 90% off; even then, I find playing this game to be an extremely boring chore, just playing to finish it and move on to the next game in my library. Considering the time I wasted on the first Ghost Warrior (which was equally boring and I felt liberated when I finished it), I probably won't play it until the end.

Review for 29/11/2015 - do not purchase this game, as servers are offline, rendering it unplayable. No compres este juego, servidores offline. No puedes jugar. While I was able to play, I enjoyed it. As the song by the Steve Miller Band goes...: go on take the money and run uh uh uhhh! go on take the money and run go on take the money and run go on take the money and run https://youtu.be/-wcfugcollu?t=54 --- english - 73 minutes playing the game, omfg just an hour in and this game is awesome! Some guns are overpowered and matchmaking can be unfair at times, but hey, BF3 has worse matchmaking. As a newbie, I was matched with higher-level players who didn't seem like real humans - you could shoot them in the face and nothing would happen.

Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? This puzzle platforming game stars a little guy with a fez who goes around collecting little bits to form a cube and navigating through a fairly large, branching map. The game is quite amusing, and running through it to complete the game was quite enjoyable. However, it can become semi-frustrating if you want to get all the cubes and achievements. To get all the cubes, you'll need to crack codes that you'll have to decipher. These can take a few seconds or frustrate you into looking up a guide (*raises hand* I gave up -_-). The guide, 'A Complete Guide to Fez!!!'

It's not hard for me to see why others like this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing, I have a Vive and I'm much more interested in playing room-sized games with the controllers. Beyond that, the game is initially awe-inspiring in the scale of its universe, but I also felt that same scale hindered my enjoyment. The learning curve and the time required to do anything interesting at the beginning were both too large for me. Perhaps if I were more patient and had more time for gaming, this would be compelling to me. But I don't have either, and there are plenty more VR games I'd rather spend my time on.

Hands down, my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun Rambo types need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always result in death unless it just grazes you. Rounds drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are required if you wish to remain on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload halfway through your magazine all the time, then you will have a pouch full of half-full mags. You can't run forever. If you sprint for a while, your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you've caught your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a windowsill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing upright.

Let me start by saying I didn't purchase EU when it first came out, and I got it on sale, which included EW. As a result, I never experienced the issues that some people claim to have had with that game. I loved that game, however; it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you did things right. As for XCOM2, I love it - the game plays pretty well for me on medium, and I'm running a GTX560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game was set to high, and it was running a bit sluggishly, but not to the point of being unplayable. When I dropped it down to medium, it smoothed out. I'm not sure if I'm just lucky when it comes to having issues with games, but it seems that most of the negative reviews sound like they're coming from some really entitled individuals.

+RPG levelling +wide variety of ship types +physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles +easy-to-learn resource management +dark humor -grind-intensive (if underutilizing civilian station types) -subpar AI teammates -limited variety of equipment types -limited variety of levelling skills (i.e., no branching) Listen, this game is incredibly fun. Despite the drawbacks, there's still variety and strategy to be found. It starts off fast and remains engaging. Although equipment options are limited, it feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to extend the game's life is through mods. Fight for Universe is the standout, but Big Fight for Beef is also excellent.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty as more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe arrive in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's growing economic power to Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the over 20 government leaders and heads of state attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be subdued. Anti-globalisation campaigners have cancelled a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to run concurrently with the WEF's more exclusive event in Davos.

Deadline nears for Fiat-GM deal. Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on 1 February to settle a disagreement over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, part of an alliance agreed upon in 2000. GM, whose own European operations are struggling financially, no longer wants to own the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent Fiat shares down 1.2% on Tuesday, following Monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payoff. The US firm is thought to be offering approximately $2bn (£1.06bn) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued the deal was voided by Fiat's decision to sell off its finance arm and halve GM's stake through a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted from a competitive bid between GM and DaimlerChrysler to ally with Fiat.

Cardinal criticises Iraq war, stating billions of pounds spent on conflict in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to alleviate poverty. Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor made the comments on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance in his Christmas midnight mass. The cardinal used a Christmas message to denounce the war in Iraq as a "terrible" waste of resources. He and the Archbishop of Canterbury have both spoken out against the war. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day slot, he criticised the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to bring people "out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease". The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make poverty history".

British stars denied major Oscars. British hopes of winning major Oscars were dashed as UK stars failed to win acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's 'Vera Drake' failed to take the director or screenplay awards, and there was no prize for star Imelda Staunton. Kate Winslet also lost to Best Actress Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo failed to win Best Supporting Actor awards. The UK's Andrea Arnold won the Short Film award for her gritty drama 'Wasp'. Arnold, who presented children's television shows 'Number 73' and 'Motormouth' in the 1980s, said it was "totally overwhelming" to win. 'Wasp' tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, beating films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Halloween writer Debra Hill dies. Screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, best known for her work on the 1970s horror classic Halloween, has died in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it grossed over $60m (£31.3m) worldwide - a record for an independent film at that time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way up the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before she started collaborating with Carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on roles in the 1970s that were more commonly held by men.

Broadband fuels online expression as fast web access encourages more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of Britain's broadband users regularly upload content and maintain personal sites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. It states that having an always-on, fast connection is transforming the way people use the internet. Over five million households in the UK have broadband, and this number is growing rapidly. The Demos report examined the impact of broadband on people's internet habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. More significantly, the report argues, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active online role.

Yukos heads back to US courts as Russian oil and gas company Yukos is due in a US court on Thursday, continuing its fight for survival. The firm is being broken up by Russian authorities to pay a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. The unit was sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm Rosneft after the state auction was disrupted. Yukos lawyers now claim the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to pursue any company that buys its assets, using all available legal means.

Voters flock to blog awards site; voting is underway for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed due to an overwhelming number of visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a top US dictionary naming "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and says that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to US research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing' - The China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to obey a government order to halt construction of one of its giant dams, the Chinese state press has reported. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the sister Xiluodu Dam, according to the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is one of 30 large-scale construction projects ordered to stop due to a lack of proper environmental checks. The Beijing News stated that the company may instead opt to pay a fine. The firm has also disregarded orders to stop construction at two of its other projects - the Three Gorges underground power plant and the Three Gorges project electrical power supply plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for not carrying out mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy 2-0 victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off Richard Dunne, to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient, and they managed to fashion just one clear chance - a Paul Scholes header over the bar, with their overall performance lacking cohesion.

Wales 'must learn health lessons' - the new health minister for Wales says there are lessons to learn from England in tackling waiting lists. Dr Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the job after Jane Hutt was sacked, admitted "big challenges" but insisted the "essentials" were in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats said Dr Gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile, Ms Hutt defended her record, saying waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr Gibbons, who was a GP in Blaengwynfi, in the Upper Afan Valley, before becoming AM for Aberavon, said NHS staff wanted a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform." One of the biggest problems that had faced Ms Hutt during her five-and-a-half years as the assembly's first health minister was the lengthy waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson hails Man Utd's resolve. Manchester United's Alex Ferguson has praised his players' gritty performance in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our toughest away game of the season and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with plenty of good passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We showed lots of character and determination and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come and Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also hailed senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield which we needed and which few other players possess.

A documentary film about the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be showcased at this year's Berlin Film Festival. 'A Different Story' will screen in the Panorama section of the festival, running from 10-20 February. The film features the singer candidly discussing his career and personal life, from his days in Wham! to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February. Director Southan Morris and Executive Producer Andy Stephens will also be in attendance. The 93-minute film sees Michael reflecting on his early days in Wham! and his later career, including his high-profile legal battles with record label Sony and his outspoken stance against the Iraq War and American politics.

Downloads enter US singles chart; digital music downloads are being included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate digital download chart. Green Day's 'Boulevard of Broken Dreams' is currently number two in Billboard's Pop chart, and tops its digital song chart. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Songs chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its revamped Hot 100 chart. Its second new chart - the Pop 100 - also combines airplay, digital and physical sales but confines its airplay information to US radio stations that play chart-topping music.

Anti-spam laws have taken a toll on a notorious spammer, as the self-declared "spam king" of the net seeks bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the man behind Optinrealbig.com and billions of junk mail messages, stated that lawsuits had forced the company into Chapter 11. Optinrealbig was fighting several legal battles, most notably against Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. The company said filing for Chapter 11 would help it attempt to resolve its legal issues while continuing to trade. Listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, Optinrealbig was sued in December 2003 for sending mail messages that breached anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who alleged that Mr. Richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini. Tottenham Sporting Director Frank Arnesen has denied that Coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There had been newspaper speculation that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "There is only one reason he resigned, and that is his own personal issues." He has recently spoken to me and said this matter is entirely personal." Arnesen said he was unable to shed any light on the problems that caused Santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added: "Jacques has never disclosed exactly what it was. But I trust him; you have to accept it. I think we should respect his decision.

Ireland surged past the Scots as they maintained their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory over Scotland at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by halftime. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy come to Edinburgh, but they again struggled to convert pressure into points.

Economy focus for election battle: Britain's economic future will be at the heart of Labour's poll campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has stated. He was speaking after cabinet members held their final meeting at No 10 before the expected election announcement. He said voters would acknowledge that Labour had brought stability and growth, and would continue to do so. Meanwhile, the Tories outlined their plans to tackle "yob culture" and the Lib Dems provided more details about their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury wrote to all three parties, urging them not to fight the election by exploiting people's fears. In an open letter, he called on them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime, and instead focus on the issues.

Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA's championships in Sheffield. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not participate in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title at the British trials. In-form James McIlroy will hope to confirm his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in tremendous form on the European circuit in recent weeks, showcasing his speed. He is one of the fastest 800m runners globally this winter and already seems assured of a place in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg in the European championships, having been ranked number three in the world 3000m ranking, with Cragg occupying the top spot.

Robinson targets dual code success as England rugby union captain Jason Robinson aims for dual code success over Australia on Saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international before switching codes in 2000, leads England against Australia at Twickenham at 1430 GMT. And at 1815 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team face Australia in the final of the Tri-Nations tournament. "Beating the Aussies in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league," said Robinson. England have the chance to seal their third autumn international victory after successive wins over Canada and South Africa, as well as gaining revenge for June's 51-15 defeat by the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain could end 34 years of failure against Australia with a win at Elland Road.

Warning over tsunami aid website: Net users are being advised to avoid a scam website claiming to collect cash on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears plausible as it uses an outdated version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee webpage. However, DEC has no connection with the fake site and has contacted the police about it. The site is the latest in a long list of scams attempting to exploit the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam email currently circulating. The message's subject line reads "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal" and its text features poor grammar and bad spelling characteristic of many phishing attempts.

Iraq to invite phone licence bids. Iraq is to invite bids for two telephone licences, stating it aims to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids have been invited from local, Arab and foreign companies, Iraq's Ministry of Communications announced. The winner will work in partnership with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry stated that it wants to increase Iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate" from about 4.5% today to around 25% within 10 years. It also hopes to develop a "highly visible and dynamic telecommunication sector". Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 February. A road-show for investors is also planned in Amman, Jordan.

More women are turning to net security as older individuals and women increasingly take charge of protecting home computers against malicious online attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women purchasing programs to protect PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% annually between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted for net security firm Preventon, shows that security messages are reaching a diverse range of surfers. It is thought that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retirees. Over the last three years, this figure has increased by an average of 13.2%. However, more retired women (53%) were purchasing security software than retired men. The research reflects the changing stereotype and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the greater risks posed by high-speed broadband internet connections to surfers.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music players can hold up to 10,000 songs, a considerable amount of space to fill. However, more and more iPod owners are filling that space with audio content created by an unpredictable assortment of producers. This phenomenon is called "podcasting," and its strongest proponent is former MTV host and VJ (video jockey) Adam Curry. Podcasting takes its name from the Apple iPod, although an iPod is not required to create or listen to a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show that podcasters create, often in the comfort of their own home. They need only a microphone, a PC, and some editing software to produce their shows, which they then upload to the internet for others to download and listen to, free of charge.

Andrea Levy, the Orange Prize winner, has seen her novel 'Small Island' win the Whitbread Novel of the Year award. She is now the favourite to win the overall prize after beating Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's 'The Line of Beauty'. Geraldine McCaughrean has picked up the children's fiction award for the third time for 'Not the End of the World'. All the category winners will compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which carries a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will meet on 25 January to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has placed London-based Levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win the prestigious award.

Yukos seeks court action on sale. Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm that has acquired its main asset. Yukos has stated it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20bn in damages. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to have Baikal's assets frozen after the Russian government disregarded a US court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for acquiring the unit remain unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that Baikal - which acquired the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4bn (261bn roubles, £4.8bn) on Sunday at a state-provoked auction - has strong ties with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-biggest oil producer.

Hearts 2-1 Livingston. Hearts wrapped up their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie against Livingston with two goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller scored inside the opening 60 seconds, heading over Colin Meldrum and into the net from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister himself scored the second when he met Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post to put the game beyond the visitors' reach. Craig Easton headed in a contentious goal after an hour, but Hearts held on. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken had clumsily fouled Miller 35 yards from goal. McAllister floated the free kick into the Livi box, and Miller outjumped the static visiting defence to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, the home side doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, crossing to the back post where McAllister raced in to head past Meldrum.

Sun offers processing by the hour; Sun Microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service, allowing customers requiring huge computing power to rent it by the hour. Sun Grid costs users $1 (53p) for an hour's worth of processing and storage power on systems maintained by Sun. So-called grid computing is the latest buzz phrase in a company that believes computing capacity is as important a commodity as hardware and software. Sun likened grid computing to the development of electricity. The system could mature similarly to utilities such as electricity and water, said Sun's Chief Operating Officer, Jonathan Schwartz. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked during a webcast launching Sun's quarterly Network Computing event in California.

Jamieson issues warning to bigots: Scotland's Justice Minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she intends to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson stated that exclusion orders are one of a series of measures being considered in the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism. She commended Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in tackling the problem. However, the minister emphasized that stopping sectarian abuse associated with Old Firm matches is a key objective. Ms Jamieson was speaking ahead of the third-round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the Executive. Last week, Ms Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met with supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

UK debut for Kevin Spacey movie. Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of the new film, Beyond the Sea, in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who, as Darin, sings all 18 songs on the film's soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife - real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

Leeds v Saracens (Fri) Headingley Friday, 25 February 2000 GMT The Tykes have signed Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack, while Kevin Sorrell comes in at outside centre. - Friday's game at Headingley got the go-ahead on Friday after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an unclear future as the fixed line phone in your home could soon be an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia reveals that an increasing number of people are using their mobile phone for every call they make or take. According to the study, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now rely solely on a mobile. It showed that people retain their fixed line phone because call charges are lower, but most of those questioned said the future was undoubtedly mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research showed that mobiles and fixed phones served different purposes. Home phones were used for longer, more in-depth calls, but conversations on mobiles tended to be shorter, often between mobiles and with friends. In the UK, 69% of those questioned said they turned to their fixed phone because it was still more economical to use than a mobile.

A group of MPs has attempted to increase pressure on Tony Blair regarding reform to the House of Lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber, in which 70% of members would be elected. MPs and peers have failed to agree on reform since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats. The group claims it can win support for removing the last 92 hereditary peers. The government postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers, citing low chances of success due to opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has argued that consensus is necessary for reforms. There have been suggestions that Labour's manifesto will include proposals for changing at least the powers of the Lords.

Disappointed Scott makes solid start. Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a promising debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equalled the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final. He won his heat in 7.64secs but ran 0.04secs slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix Circuit final, narrowly missing his heat time.

A US woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP), alleging its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a specific date. The unnamed woman from Georgia claims a chip inside the cartridge informs the printer that it needs refilling, even when it doesn't. The lawsuit seeks to represent anyone in the US who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer firm, declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges utilize chip technology to sense when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change. However, the suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date, regardless of whether they are empty or not.

Virgin Radio offers 3G broadcast. UK broadcaster Virgin Radio says it will become the first station in the world to offer radio via 3G mobiles. The radio station, in partnership with technology firm Sydus, will broadcast on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners will be able to download software from the Virgin website, enabling the service. James Cridland, Head of New Media at Virgin Radio, said: "It places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station made available, followed by two digital stations: Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland said: "This application will enable anyone, anywhere, to listen to Virgin Radio simply with their phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music to perform at Isle of Wight bill. Roxy Music will appear at June's Isle of Wight music festival, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM have already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, which takes place from 10-12 June. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will take to the stage on the Saturday night of the festival. The band is also working in the studio on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Roxy Music were formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's 'Virginia Plain', with other hits including 'Street Life', 'Love Is the Drug', and the 1981 John Lennon cover, 'Jealous Guy'.

Captains lining up for aid match: Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is one of four Six Nations captains included in the Northern Hemisphere squad for the IRB Rugby Aid match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Gordon Bullock of Scotland, and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also in the Northern party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod MacQueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," he said. It will be a chance for Woodward to assess some of his options before unveiling his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer months. "The game promises to be a great spectacle," he added.

Spirit awards hail the comedy that has dominated this year's independent spirit awards, winning all six of the awards for which it was nominated. It was named best film while Alexander Payne won best director and best screenplay, along with writing partner Jim Taylor. It also won acting awards for stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. Sideways is tipped to do well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, are given to films made outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who took best actress for her role as a Colombian drug smuggler in the drama Maria Full of Grace. Moreno is also nominated for best actress at the Oscars. The best first screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for Maria Full of Grace.

Prince crowned 'top music earner' - Prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004, beating artists such as Madonna and Elton John in US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer banked $56.5m (£30.4m) from concerts, album sales, and publishing royalties with his Musicology tour and album. He kept Madonna in second place, as she earned $54.9m (£29.5m) while embarking on her global Re-Invention tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel were in 10th place, their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9m (£13.4m) last year. "Prince returned to centre stage after a decade in commercial obscurity," the magazine reported. The singer's 2004 tour took $90.3m (£48.5m) in ticket sales, and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album, Musicology.

Wal-mart fights back at accusers; two big US names have launched advertising campaigns to "set the record straight" about their products and corporate behavior. The world's biggest retailer, Wal-mart, took out over 100 full-page adverts in national newspapers. The group is trying to counter criticism over its pay deals, benefits package, and promotion strategy. Meanwhile, the pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly is planning a campaign against "false" claims about its product Prozac. Wal-mart kicked off the battle with adverts in newspapers like The Wall Street Journal, using an open letter from company president Lee Scott, saying it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth". "There are many 'urban legends' circulating these days about Wal-mart, but facts are facts.

Tories outlining policing plans: local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the Conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard said the new role would replace "ineffective" police authorities. He said the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The Lib Dems said the plan could let extreme groups run policing, while Labour criticised "unrealistic" Tory promises on policing. Responding to the plans, the chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank and file officers, said it was essential operational independence was retained. Jan Berry said: "It is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches. These plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground," she warned, citing concerns over potential politicisation.

At a glance: Tory health checks - the UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: people coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU will be affected. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with high TB rates, they would have to undergo a chest x-ray and further tests if necessary. All people from outside the European Union who want to stay a year or more will have to undergo a full medical. Tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV will be tested for. A positive TB test would automatically result in visa applications being rejected. All other conditions would be dealt with on a case-by-case basis.

Paris promise raises Welsh hopes: has there been a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris? And can the Welsh revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? Those are the two questions occupying not just Wales supporters but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two of the three Grand Slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades". Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games I've ever played in". A crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply observed: "there was a French half and a Welsh half, that's how it felt.

Doves soar to UK album summit; Manchester rock band Doves have entered the UK album chart at number one with their new release, Some Cities. The trio replace flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the top spot. The album follows single Black and White Town, which reached number six. R&B star Nelly has the new number one single with Over and Over, which sees him team up with Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, as do The Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, (Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame, entered the chart at number three, one place ahead of Girls Aloud's Wake Me Up. Hip-hop performer Akon's Locked Up is at number five, while hotly-tipped Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs have their second chart hit at number six with Oh My God.

Davies favours Gloucester future, Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to stay with English side Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but that he would prefer to remain where he is. Davies, one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is only on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, the hooker has proved his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to secure a new deal next season. The summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region left Davies without a contract and forced him to take a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he gained match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, he admitted before his move to Gloucester that he was unhappy with the way he was treated.

Cabinet anger at Brown's cash raid: ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon Brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Mr Raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. However, he emphasized that local governments must deliver good services without significant council tax rises. The central government cash is part of a £1bn package to help local authorities in England keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is likely to be a general election year. Mr Raynsford noted that nearly all central government departments have an interest in well-run local authorities.

Israeli club looks to Africa; four African players, including Zimbabwe goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, are set to play for Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin is the first Arab side to ever compete in European competition and will face English Premiership side Newcastle United in the first round. The Warriors' goalkeeper, Murambadoro, who gained recognition at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, helped Bnei Sakhnin overcome Albania's Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. Murambadoro recently moved to Israel after a brief stint with South African club Hellenic. The club won the Israeli Cup final last season and is based in Sakhnin, near Haifa. The club has a strong ethos and is a high-profile promoter of peace and co-operation within Israel.

New drink limit 'would cut toll' - more lives than previously thought could be saved by reducing drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. University College London research claims that lowering the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives annually. The findings are being published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs are due to vote on the government's Road Safety Bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, carried out by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, says that lowering the limit would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the UK's roads compared to 2003. He estimates that this would save the country £119m annually. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 Department of Transport document, suggested such a move could save around 50 lives a year.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1×1 μm^2 diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512×512 μm^2. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline, thereby eliminating the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process and consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The system's functionality is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting, confirming its effectiveness.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to mitigate the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize AVs to seek centrally controlled system optimal (SO) routing by saving on tolls, while user equilibrium (UE) seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HDVs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering a mixed fleet of AVs and HDVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. In addition to inducing ever larger and more tangible objects into a regime of quantum behavior, this new capability has inspired ideas of utilizing mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity precludes access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Indeed, early optomechanical proposals noted the possibility to overcome this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Although there have been experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, these have not yet accessed nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews provide product evaluations to aid customers in making informed decisions. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be manipulated using fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers, who continually adapt and develop increasingly sophisticated spamming strategies to evade deployed detectors. Spamming strategies are difficult to capture, as they can vary rapidly over time, differ across spammers and target products, and, more critically, often remain unknown. Furthermore, most existing detectors prioritize detection accuracy, which does not align well with the goal of maintaining trustworthy product evaluations. To address these challenges, we formulate a minimax game where spammers and spam detectors compete with each other on practical goals that are not solely based on detection accuracy. The Nash equilibria of the game lead to stable detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we employed the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Among this family, we identified a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We defined a measure of the robustness of an ultra-high-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses was found superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we study the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to nonconvexity, multiple local minima exist that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We show that all local minima share a common structural form that partially identifies the component centers of the true mixture, in the sense that each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our results apply to the setting where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition, and are valid even when the number of components is over- or under-specified. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain sharper results in terms of the scaling with the separation between the components.

We consider the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold.
